item.title: Libyan Official Abducted Amid Unrest in Capital
item.description: The City Council in Tripoli, where the deputy intelligence chief was seized, called a general strike to demand that militias leave the city.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Demonstrators on Sunday protested the presence of militias in Tripoli, where Libyaâ€™s deputy intelligence chief was kidnapped.

item.title: Amsterdam Journal: Where St. Nicholas Has His Black Pete(s), Charges of Racism Follow
item.description: Portrayed by people in blackface makeup, Peter sports outlandish Renaissance costumes, with thick red lips and frizzy hairdo wigs or fake dreadlocks.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN TAGLIABUE
item.media:credit: Herman Wouters for The New York Times
item.media:description: St. Nicholas in Amsterdam on Sunday with his Black Petes, whom critics denounce as racist caricatures. Later on Sunday, a demonstration against Black Pete occurred in Amsterdam.

item.title: Exiting President Reflects on Georgia
item.description: In an interview last month, in the waning days of his presidency, Mikheil Saakashvili boasted that Georgia was closer to becoming an established democracy.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Leli Blagonravova/Presidential Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Giorgi Margvelashvili heading to take the oath of office in Tbilisi, the capital.

item.title: West Faces Challenge in Moving Syrian Chemical Arms Through Battlefields
item.description: Officials say the shipments will be vulnerable to attack as they travel past the ruins of a war that has raged for two and a half years.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER, THOM SHANKER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Syrian rebels took up positions inside a damaged house last week in Deir al-Zour, in eastern Syria. There are fears of attacks on shipments of chemical arms.

item.title: Former President of Chile Poised to Regain Her Seat
item.description: A former presidentâ€™s campaign promises, on education, health, social security and taxes, proved attractive in a nation of stark inequality.
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: Afghan Talks at Impasse Before Vote, Officials Say
item.description: Two senior Afghan officials said on Sunday that negotiations with the United States were at an impasse, just days before an Afghan grand council is scheduled to meet.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: American negotiatorsâ€™ insistence that United States troops retain the right to enter Afghan homes is a point of contention between Afghan and American officials.

item.title: Warnings of New Turmoil as Pakistan Pursues a Treason Case for Musharraf
item.description: The government said it had asked the Supreme Court to establish a panel to try Gen. Pervez Musharraf on accusations that he subverted the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bitcoin Scandal Reflects Popularity of Virtual Currency in China
item.description: Restrictions on Chinese citizensâ€™ ability to trade in their own currency, the renminbi, have contributed to the embrace of digital alternatives.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: Bitcoins have strong appeal for Chinese investors.

item.title: Growing Clamor About Inequities of Climate Crisis
item.description: The devastation in the Philippines has revived the debate over how to address the disproportionate effects of climate change on poorer countries, an issue that has gained momentum but faces daunting challenges.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Mohamed Abdiwahab/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: People evacuating after a storm hit the Puntland region of Somalia.

item.title: Ravaged Philippine City Ponders a Grim Road Ahead
item.description: Guiuan escaped the deadly storm surge that hit Tacloban, but it was still devastated and faces an uncertain recovery despite the arrival of international aid.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family inÂ Guiuan outside a makeshift shelter they constructed after their home was destroyed.Â The town bore the full brunt of Typhoon Haiyan.

item.title: Guerrilla Group Says It Killed 2 From a Greek Extremist Party in an Athens Suburb
item.description: A previously unknown leftist group has claimed responsibility for the shootings of members of the neofascist party Golden Dawn this month.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Passenger Jet Crash in City East of Moscow Kills 50
item.description: A Boeing 737-500 that originated in Moscow apparently was making a second attempt to land when it slammed into the ground in Kazan, a regional capital east of Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Rescue workers at the scene of an airline crash in Kazan, the capital of the Tatarstan republic of Russia.

item.title: Bloomberg News Suspends Reporter Whose Article on China Was Not Published
item.description: After disputing reports that top editors had killed an article on China for political reasons, Bloomberg News suspended the reporter Michael Forsythe.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY

item.title: Philippine Community Groups Fill Vacuum in Typhoonâ€™s Aftermath
item.description: In the parts of the nation where local governmentsâ€™ capacity to respond to the devastation was greatly diminished, religious and community groups have vastly expanded their roles.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families sheltered inside the Tacloban City Convention Center on Friday.

item.title: Doris Lessing, Author Who Swept Aside Convention, Is Dead at 94
item.description: Ms. Lessing was an uninhibited and outspoken novelist who produced dozens of novels, short stories, essays and poems, embarking on dizzying and at times stultifying literary experiments.
item.dc:creator: By HELEN T. VERONGOS
item.media:description: Doris Lessing in 1992 in her garden at home in London.

item.title: U.S. Military Considers a Mission to Train Libyan Security Forces
item.description: The mission would be part of the Pentagonâ€™s evolving national security strategy to build counterterrorism capacity among local forces in allied nations, American officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: 9 Attackers and 2 Officers Reported Killed in Tense Western China
item.description: The assailants were shot dead Saturday night after they tried to storm a police station in the restive province of Xinjiang. Two police officers also died in the attack.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Relief Supplies Pour Into Philippines, but Remote Areas Still Suffer
item.description: While hard-hit urban areas are finally getting adequate supplies, the rural hinterland has been largely left to fend for itself in the week since Typhoon Haiyan hit.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan in Guiuan, on Samar Island.

item.title: India Ink: With Great Reluctance, India Bids Farewell to Tendulkar
item.description: On Nov. 15, 1989, Sachin Tendulkar made his international cricket debut as a curly-haired 16-year-old prodigy. Twenty-four years later, almost to the day, he departed from his beloved sport to the cries of an ever-adoring nation.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:description: Supporters of cricketer Sachin Tendulkar in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Saturday.

item.title: For Son of a Nazi-Era Dealer, a Private Life Amid a Tainted Trove of Art
item.description: Cornelius Gurlitt, the reclusive son of a Nazi-era art dealer, told a German newsmagazine that the confiscation of some 1,280 masterworks from his home was more devastating than his sisterâ€™s death.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Staatsanwaltschaft Augsburg, via Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Artworks among the trove that Cornelius Gurlitt kept for years in his Munich apartment.Â From top left:Â "Don Quixote and Sancho Panza" by Honore Daumier, "Riders on the Beach" by Max Liebermann, "Study of a Woman Nude, Standing, Arms Raised, Hands Crossed Above Head" by Auguste Rodin, "Child at Table" by Otto Griebel, "Sa Giustina in Pra della Vale" byÂ Antonio Canaletto, "Male Portrait" by Ludwig Godenschweg, "Couple" by Hans Christoph, "Mother and Child" by Erich Fraass, "Couple in a Landscape" by Conrad Felixmueller, "View of the Seine Valley" by Theodore Rousseau, "Monk" by Christoph Voll, "Tram" by Bernhard Kretschmar, "Thinking Woman" by Fritz Maskos, "The Master Exploder Hantsch" by Christoph Voll, "Female Nude" by Ludwig Godenschweg, "Seated Woman/Woman Sitting in Armchair" by Henri Matisse, "Veiled Woman" by Otto Griebel, "Girl at Table" by Wilhelm Lachnit, "Dompteuse" by Otto Dix, and "Male Nude" by Bonaventura Genelli.

item.title: Hurdles Seen for Change to Chinaâ€™s One-Child Rule
item.description: A state official said provincial-level governments would decide when to carry out the new policy, and he stressed that the government had no plans to further relax family size restrictions.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Aleksandr Serebrov, Cosmonaut of Fettered Times, Dies at 69
item.description: Mr. Serebrov, who once held a spacewalk record, flew four missions for a program that abandoned Soviet ambitions for Russian spare parts.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Aleksandr Serebrov was one of the few cosmonauts to fly for both the Soviet Union and its successor, the Russian republic.

item.title: Keith Bradsher Answers Readersâ€™ Questions on the Philippines
item.description: Mr. Bradsher, a Times reporter covering the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, answered readersâ€™ questions about doing his job under difficult conditions and the relief efforts underway.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: JoaquÃ­n HernÃ¡ndez Galicia, Leader of Powerful Mexican Union, Dies at 91
item.description: Mr. HernÃ¡ndez Galicia led a union of 200,000 workers employed by Mexicoâ€™s huge state-owned oil company, Pemex, and they revered him for the generous benefits he won for them.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: JoaquÃ­nÂ HernÃ¡ndez Galicia and his union were widely viewed as corrupt.

item.title: A Russian GPS Using U.S. Soil Stirs Spy Fears
item.description: American spy agencies fear that allowing monitor stations in the United States for Russiaâ€™s version of GPS could compromise American intelligence.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Pedro Ladeira/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: A technician from Russia's space agency at a monitor station that opened in Brazil.
